PT J
AU Arvidson, PS
AF Arvidson, PS
TI Transformations in consciousness - Continuity, the self and marginal
   consciousness
SO JOURNAL OF CONSCIOUSNESS STUDIES
LA English
DT Article
ID ATTENTION; SEARCH
AB The term 'consciousness' is usually reserved only for the focus of attention. This restriction empties the phenomenology Of consciousness of some of its richness. Rather than conceiving of consciousness as one-dimensional, researchers should consider that consciousness has a three-dimensional organization. Conscious presentations are structured in a focus, context and margin pattern. Inclusion of these other dimensions of consciousness as consciousness (rather than, for example, as unconsciousness) is important for an adequate relation between scientific method and phenomenology. The problem becomes especially acute when transformations in consciousness - attentional and temporal continuity - are considered. Using Aron Gurwitsch's work, this paper presents an alternative to Galen Strawson's view of consciousness and rite self as an example of the usefulness of this fuller conception of consciousness. I argue here that there is significant attentional and temporal continuity in consciousness, and that this continuity, provides for a sense of the self as a distinct, but continuous experience.
C1 Seattle Univ, Dept Philosophy, Seattle, WA 98122 USA.
RP Arvidson, PS (reprint author), Seattle Univ, Dept Philosophy, Seattle, WA 98122 USA.

PT J
AU Zirion, AQ
AF Zirion, AQ
TI Phenomenology in Mexico: A historical profile
SO CONTINENTAL PHILOSOPHY REVIEW
LA English
DT Article
AB The paper presents a journey along the history of phenomenology (Husserlian Phenomenology or phenomenology derived from Husserl) in Mexico, dealing mainly with its appropriation in the field of philosophy proper. The survey covers almost the whole century, leaving out only the last years and the present situation. Although all those philosophers who cam in touch with phenomenology in a significant way in that period are mentioned here, particular attention is laid upon three figures and their meaning in Mexican philosophical culture: they are Antonio Caso, the first influential thinker and professor to dedicate a book to Husserl's philosophy; Jose Gaos, who enjoys a well-deserved fame as teacher and translator of phenomenological works, and Jorge Portilla, the author of a most valuable phenomenological essay: Phenomenology of Relajo. Thus, in these three cases, their contributions are explored in a somewhat more detailed way.
C1 Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, Inst Investigaciones Filos, Mexico City 04510, DF, Mexico.
RP Zirion, AQ (reprint author), Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, Inst Investigaciones Filos, Mexico City 04510, DF, Mexico.

PT J
AU Sobotka, M
AF Sobotka, M
TI Contemporary descartes
SO FILOSOFICKY CASOPIS
LA Czech
DT Article
AB The central them of this article is a particular hiatus between the first and second meditations, and the remaining meditations in Meditationes de prima philosophia. In the first meditation, once the noetic priority of the subject has been established and the world of the senses has been transposed into the phenomenon of consciousness, and in the second meditation, once the subject has been established in its alleged autonomy and its function as the guarantor of all true knowledge, it may seem that the task of the meditations has at this point been fulfilled. The idea of Descartes as the creator of the ''theory of knowledge" (Erkenntnistheorie) is based on this viewpoint, and the majority of interpretations from the 19(th) and 20(th) centuries (Natorp, Cassirer: Brunschwicg) approach the main work of Descartes in this manner. A similar point of view was also taken up by the two greatest philosophers of the 20(th) century. E. Husserl sets the first two meditations of Descartes as the forerunners of phenomenology, but is disappointed by the direction he takes in the following meditations. Heidegger sees in Descartes the philosopher of a scientific and technical approach to reality, and the philosopher of the disposition of all truth in the subject. This article argues in favour of the thesis that cogito sum as the source of truth is only temporary, forced by the demand of it being provable, and it emphasises the need for further approaches to pass through "metaphysical doubt" (metaphysical dubitandi ratio). The Meditations of Descartes results in the ontoteological conception of the disposition of all truth and all fortune.
CR ADAM C, 1937, DESCARTES VIE OEUVRE, P18

PT J
AU Kvasz, L
AF Kvasz, L
TI Galileo's physics int he light of Husserl's phenomenology
SO FILOSOFICKY CASOPIS
LA Czech
DT Article
AB The aim of the paper is to confront Husserl's interpretation of Galileo's physics, from his Crisis, with the content and historical context of Galileo's scientific works. From such an confrontation it turned out, that the basic Husserlian ideas, which Husserl presented in a rather general and loose terms, can be filled with historical content and developed into a systematic and detailed account of the first phases of scientific revolution. On the Ether hand, the confrontation of Husserl's interpretations with actual history revealed also some problematic moments. The most important of them is the interpretation of the transition from Galilean physics to Cartesian philosophy, which Husserl left without any explanation.

PT J
AU Hogenova, A
AF Hogenova, A
TI On the problem of inner perception (phenomenological analysis as
   understood by Husserl and Patocka)
SO FILOZOFIA
LA Czech
DT Article
AB The paper is a contribution to the phenomenological analysis of the process of the inner perception as understood by Husserl and Patocka. It draws on the four stratas of the "stream of cogitationes" from Patocks's Introduction to Husserl's Phenomenology: the stratum of the real transcendence (the things surrounding us), the stratum of the real immanence (the internal phenomena in their objective validity, as present in common psychological considerations), the stratum of the reel immanence (the description of the singularities after the transcendental epoche), and the stratum of reel transcendence (the retention and the protention as the achievements of the passive and active sedimentation in horizontal intentionality). The author discusses the process of phenomenalization with the background as its clue element, on which, like on a screen, the appearances are displayed. The background is seen as making the appearance "clare et distincte" in its original cartesian form possible. At the same time the background is seen as a whole, a context, a horizon.
C1 Charles Univ, CR-16000 Prague 6, Czech Republic.
RP Hogenova, A (reprint author), Charles Univ, CR-16000 Prague 6, Czech Republic.

PT J
AU Casari, E
AF Casari, E
TI On Husserl's theory of wholes and parts
SO HISTORY AND PHILOSOPHY OF LOGIC
LA English
DT Article
AB The strongly innovative theory of whole-parts relations outlined by Husserl in his Third logical Investigation-to which he attributed a basic value for his entire phenomenology-has recently attracted a renewed interest. Although many important issues have been clarified (especially by Kit Fine) the subject seems still worth being revisited. To this aim Husserlian universes are introduced. These are lower bounded distributive lattices endowed with a unary operation of defect and a binary relation of isogeneity. Husserl's contents are identified with nonzero elements of a Husserlian universe and the dependence relations among contents are defined and studied starting from the idea that the defect of x is what x needs in order to 'exist' i.e., in order to be 'closed' with respect to the closure operation defined as the sup of x and its defect. It turns out that there are (at least) eight dependence relations which are worth to be considered. Many other questions concerning the world of contents (among them the proofs of the famous Husserl's Satze) may now be discussed and clarified. Then the theory of species and genera is developed. Ultimate species (for short: species) are identified with equivalence classes of contents module isogeneity, and species in general (for short: genera) are identified with arbitrary unions of species. On the basis of the relation obtaining among two contents when they are isogeneous to two contents the first of which is a part of the second it becomes possible to develop a rather satisfying interpretation of Husserl's theory of the dependencies among species and genera and of the material a priori laws. By strengthening the notion of Husserlian universe into the notion of rigid Husserlian universe, the theory of species and genera obtains a stronger version. Three models of the theory are exhibited. The first one, suggested by combinatorial-topological considerations, identifies contents with finite non-empty sets of natural numbers; the second one identifies contents with non-empty sets of formulas of a formal language; the third one (not totally 'rigid') identifies contents with positive integers.
C1 Scuola Normale Super Pisa, I-56126 Pisa, Italy.
RP Casari, E (reprint author), Scuola Normale Super Pisa, Piazza Cavalieri 7, I-56126 Pisa, Italy.

PT J
AU Welten, R
AF Welten, R
TI Michel Henry and the Cartesian soul of phenomenology
SO TIJDSCHRIFT VOOR FILOSOFIE
LA Dutch
DT Article
AB From the point of view of Husserlian philosophy, Descartes failed to achieve a transcendental phenomenological subject. According to Husserl, Descartes' ego is psychological. The contemporary French philosopher Michel Henry maintains the Descartes' "ego cogito ergo sum" implies a full phenomenological subject, not because of its transcendental disposition: on the contrary, because of its self affection, which is pure. Consciousness according to Henry is not "consciousness of something outside the self," but the pure consciousness of being affected. This is the real kernel or soul of phenomenology, which can be understood as the Cartesian soul itself. Henry develops this argumentation not only through the formulation of the ego cogito, but also by means of art. 26 of Descartes' latest work, The Passions of the Soul. In this work, the relation between "action" and "passions" is thought as an early attempt of a philosophy of consciousness. According to Henry, this remains fully neglected in the philosophies of Husserl and Heidegger. This not only implies a rehabilitation of the soul as a phenomenological object, but also the recapture of phenomenology itself, which begins not with Husserl, but with Descartes.
C1 Univ Utrecht, NL-3508 TC Utrecht, Netherlands.
RP Welten, R (reprint author), Univ Utrecht, NL-3508 TC Utrecht, Netherlands.
CR Bernet R, 1996, TIJDSCHR FILOS, V58, P735
   de Muralt A., 1985, METAPHYSIQUE PHENOME
   Derrida Jacques, 1967, VOIX PHENOMENE
   DESCARTES R, MEDITATIES
   DESCARTES R, PRINCIPIA PHILOS
   DESCARTES R, PASSIONS AME
   Gaukroger S., 1995, DESCARTES INTELLECTU
   HENRY M, 1966, REV PHILOS LOUVAIN, V64, P5
   HENRY M, 1993, ESSAYS PHILOS SCI DE, P40

PT J
AU Graver, M
AF Graver, M
TI Philo of Alexandria and the origins of Stoic propatheiai
SO PHRONESIS-A JOURNAL FOR ANCIENT PHILOSOPHY
LA English
DT Article
AB The concept of "propatheiri" or "pre-emotions" is known not only to the Roman Stoics and Christian exegetes, but also to Philo of Alexandria. Philo also supplies the term "propatheiri" at QGen 1.79. As Philo cannot have derived what he knows from Seneca (despite his visit to Rome in 39), nor from Cicero, who also mentions the point, he must have found it in older Stoic writings. The "propatheir" concept, rich in implications for the voluntariness and phenomenology of the passions proper, is thus confirmed for the Hellenistic period.
   It is not to be expected that Philo's handling of this or any concept will necessarily conform to the usage of his Stoic sources. His evidence is nonetheless of great value where it coincides with that of other witnesses. In QGen 4.73 the emphasis falls upon involuntariness and the mechanisms of impression and assent as in Epictetus fr. 9. The "propatheir" saves the virtuous person's insusceptibility to emotion exactly as it does for the Stoic spokesman in Gellius NA 19.1; this point is of some interest in view of the Christological use of this concept in Origen and Didymus. QGen 1.55 and 3.56 indicate that the occurrence of the "propatheir" is dependent upon uncertainty, and further, that for Philo, as for Seneca in Ira 2.3.4, a thought no acted upon can count as a "propatheiri". In QGen 4.15-17 and 1.79, Philo indicates that hope and perhaps laughter may be related to joy as "propatheir" to "pathos;" these assertions are not paralleled in extant Stoic texts. Further, in QGen 2.57, he names "biting and contraction" as the "eupatheia" corresponding to grief, supplying a helpful parallel for Cic. Tusc. 3.83 and Plut. Virt. Mor. 449a.
   The topic may well have been discussed by Posidonius, as suggested by Cooper and others, but Posidonius' attested innovation are rather different in character from the points which have caught the attention of Philo. Taking together the indirect evidence of Philo, Seneca, and Cicero, we may reasonably infer that the "propatheir" concept belonged already to an earlier period of Stoicism.
C1 Dartmouth Coll, Hanover, NH 03755 USA.
RP Graver, M (reprint author), Dartmouth Coll, Hanover, NH 03755 USA.
CR ABEL K, 1983, HERMES-Z KLASS PHILO, V111, P78
   [Anonymous], GENESIS, V9, P4
   [Anonymous], GENESIS
   [Anonymous], MATTHEW, V26, P41
   [Anonymous], ROMANS, V8, P38
   Aristotle, ANIMA
   Aristotle, 1912, MOTU ANIMALIUM
   ARNIM HV, 1921, STOICORUM VETERUM FR
   AULUS GELLIUS, NOCTES ATTICAE
   Brenann Tad., 1998, EMOTIONS HELLENISTIC, P21
   CHRYSIPPUS, FRAGMENTA
   CICERO, TUSCULAN DISPUTATION

PT J
AU Ghitti, JM
AF Ghitti, JM
TI Marc Richir's 'Meditations phenomenologiques'
SO REVUE PHILOSOPHIQUE DE LOUVAIN
LA French
DT Article
AB Marc Richir's Meditations phenomenologiques present themselves as a remoulding of Husserl's phenomenology into a phenomenology of the symbolic understood as the unsurpassable non-equation of a sense making itself and of a definitively unstable phenomenality. In order to elucidate the latter before any institution, it is appropriate to take up the problem of method in phenomenology: it must rest on a zig-zag inquiry and on an architectonic. But it must above all rest on a new practice of the epoche, the hyperbolic epoche, from which the dynamism of the phenomenon is set free, as a transcendental field, from its two poles, objective and subjective, each bearers of illusions needing to be unmasked.
RP Ghitti, JM (reprint author), La Champeyroune, F-43260 Saint Hostien, France.

PT J
AU Pighetti, N
AF Pighetti, N
TI Gustav Chpet: From phenomenology to a 'hermeneutic dialectic' (Husserl,
   social conscience, with translation of autobiographical sketch by Chpet)
SO REVUE DE METAPHYSIQUE ET DE MORALE
LA French
DT Article
AB This article offers a brief introduction to the work of the Russian philosopher Gustav Shpet (1879-1937), with particular emphasis on several of his works published in Russia.
   Having rejected neo-Kantian idealism, G. Shpet called into question the basic principles of philosophy as a science of knowledge and being. Shpet recognized this epistemological and ontological viewpoint into Husserl's phenomenology, which he discovered in 1910 and immediately introduced into Russia through his writings and his teaching at the University of Moscow. Shpet considered that the thesis of the single transcendental subject could only lead to an idealistic blind alley, and propounded the principle of the "social being". His research on the unity of conscience as a "social conscience" led him to develop a philosophy of language, art and culture, according to the methodological principle of what he termed "hermeneutical dialectics".
   This paper is followed by a brief philosophical autobiography written by Shpet himself in 1929 (translated by the author of the article).
CR CHPET G, 1929, GRENAT
   CHPET G, 1919, SKEPTIK EVO DUCHA
   CHPET G, 1922, ESTETICHESKIE FRAGME

PT J
AU Kohout, J
AF Kohout, J
TI On Patocka's philosophy on history
SO FILOSOFICKY CASOPIS
LA Czech
DT Article
AB Paul Ricoeur assumes Patocka's most important philosophical contribution to be, firstly. his phenomenology of the "natural world" and, secondly, his philosophy of history. Ricoeur interprets Patocka's solution to the question of the sense of history as "political Socratism", which attempts to avoid the difficulties of dogmatic historical ideologies on the one hand, and the impasse of nihilistic relativism on the other.
   Patocka's historicophilosophical position consists in the openness to sudden illumination of the total sense of being as a whole, and in calling in question and "shaking up" any partial meaningfulness that can indeed originate a temporary lightening of the existential budern of life, yet sooner or later it is domomcd to a collapse.
   I have tried to illustrate, on the basis of his analysis of modern western history in his Heretical Essays on the Philosophy of Histo,History, Patocka's understanding of the passage from Eurocentrism to the "planetary" era. Patocka employs here concepts such as "the first Europeanization" of America under the influence of the Enlightenment of the old continent; "the first Americanization" of Europe in the revolutionary conception of inalienable human rights stemming from the United Stares; and the "second Americanization'' in the gradual penetration of the principles of liberal democracy into the constitutions of the European nation states. One can perhaps also talk, in Patocka's sense, of a second Europeanization of America, initiated by the emigration of representatives of European culture between the two World Wars and continuing today in an Americo-European dialogue.
CR DUBSKY I, 1990, KACIRSKE ESEJE FILOS, P5
   KARFIK F, 1997, JW GOETHE FAUST PRVN, P63
   KOHAK E, 1987, KRIZE ROZUMU PRIROZE
   LOWITOVA V, 1997, FILOS CAS, P800
   Major L, 1996, FILOS CAS, V44, P605
   PATOCK J, 1981, ESSAIS HERETIQUES PH, P15
   RICOEUR P, 1997, FILOS CAS, P742
NR 7

PT J
AU Lubcke, P
AF Lubcke, P
TI A semantic interpretation of Husserl's epoche
SO SYNTHESE
LA English
DT Article
AB This paper presents an interpretation of Husserl's phenomenological epoche or bracketing ( Einklammerung), which makes it possible to compare his position with philosophical programs developed within the framework of modern analytical philosophy. At the same time it asks in what sense Husserl's phenomenology is a form of idealism or exceeds the traditional discussion of idealism versus realism.
C1 Univ Copenhagen, Dept Pedagogy Philosophy & Rhetor, DK-2300 Copenhagen S, Denmark.
RP Lubcke, P (reprint author), Univ Copenhagen, Dept Pedagogy Philosophy & Rhetor, Njalsgade 80, DK-2300 Copenhagen S, Denmark.
CR HELD K, 1966, LEBENDIGE GEGENWART, V23, P121
   HUSSERL H, 1970, LOGICAL INVESTIGATIO
   HUSSERL H, 1960, CARTESIAN MEDITATION
   HUSSERL H, 1950, HUSSERLIANA
   Husserl H, 1970, CRISIS EUROPEAN SCI
   HUSSERL H, 1962, IDEAS GEN INTRO PURE

PT J
AU Heinamaa, S
AF Heinamaa, S
TI Merleau-Ponty's modification of phenomenology: Cognition, passion and
   philosophy
SO SYNTHESE
LA English
DT Article
AB This paper problematizes the analogy that Hubert Dreyfus has presented between phenomenology and cognitive science. It argues that Dreyfus presents Merleau-Ponty's modification of Husserl's phenomenology in a misleading way. He ignores the idea of philosophy as a radical interrogation and self-responsibility that stems from Husserl's work and recurs in Merleau-Ponty's Phenomenology of Perception. The paper focuses on Merleau-Ponty's understanding of the phenomenological reduction. It shows that his critical idea was not to restrict the scope of Husserl's reductions but to study the conditions of possibility for the thetic acts. Merleau-Ponty argued, following Husserl's texts, that the thetic acts rest on the basis of primordial pre-thetic experience. This layer of experience cannot, by its nature, be explicated or clarified, but it can be questioned and unveiled. This is the recurrent task of phenomenological philosophy, as Merleau-Ponty understands it.
C1 Univ Helsinki, Acad Finland, Dept Philosophy, FIN-00014 Helsinki, Finland.
RP Heinamaa, S (reprint author), Univ Helsinki, Acad Finland, Dept Philosophy, POB 24, FIN-00014 Helsinki, Finland.

PT J
AU Ogawa, T
